narration: Welcome to this presentation on total internal reflection.  We'll explore this fascinating optical phenomenon.

title: Understanding Refraction
content:
Light bends when passing between mediums.
Refractive index determines the bending angle.
Snell's Law describes this relationship.
image_desc:
A diagram showing a light ray bending as it passes from air into water, illustrating the concept of refraction.  Type: diagram

### Video Suggestion:
N/A
narration: First let's review refraction.  Light bends when it travels from one medium to another like from air to water. The amount of bending depends on the refractive indices of the two materials.  Snell's Law mathematically describes this relationship.

title: The Critical Angle
content:
Angle of incidence where refraction angle is 90 degrees.
Beyond this angle, total internal reflection occurs.
Dependent on refractive indices of both mediums.
image_desc:
A diagram showing a light ray approaching the boundary between two mediums at different angles, illustrating the critical angle and the transition to total internal reflection. Type: diagram

### Video Suggestion:
N/A
narration: As the angle of incidence increases the angle of refraction also increases.  There's a specific angle called the critical angle where the refracted ray travels along the boundary at 90 degrees.

title: Total Internal Reflection Explained
content: (Caption below the image) Total internal reflection occurs when the angle of incidence exceeds the critical angle.
image_desc:
A diagram showing a light ray undergoing total internal reflection within a glass prism.  The light ray is completely reflected back into the prism. Type: diagram

### Video Suggestion:
N/A
narration: Beyond the critical angle the light ray doesn't refract into the second medium instead it's completely reflected back into the first medium. This is total internal reflection.

title: Applications of Total Internal Reflection
content:
**Column 1: Optical Fibers**
Light transmission over long distances.
Medical imaging (endoscopes).
High-speed internet connections.
**Column 2: Prisms**
Reflecting light at 90 degrees.
Binoculars and periscopes.
Other optical instruments.
image_desc:
A split image showing an optical fiber cable on one side and a prism reflecting light on the other side. Type: photo

narration: Total internal reflection has many practical applications.  Optical fibers use this principle to transmit light signals over long distances crucial for communications and medical imaging.  Prisms also utilize total internal reflection for efficient light redirection in various optical instruments.

title: Conclusion
content: (Caption below the image) Total internal reflection is a fundamental optical phenomenon with significant practical applications.
